case_name: Ahmad Hafiz Khan v. Mohd. Hasan Khan

facts.text: Mohd. Yusaf obtained a money decree for Rs. 1277/7/- against Ahmad Hafiz Khan on January 14, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: One Mohd. Yusaf obtained a money decree for Rs. 1277/7/- against the appellant, Ahmad Hafiz Khan, on January 14, 1950.

facts.text: Attachment of two annas and 5-7/45 pies share of Ahmad Hafiz Khan in Mouza Tumhari, Tahsil Sakti, District Bilaspur, alongwith sir and khudkasht lands was made on September 28, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of the decree Mohd. Yusaf attached two annas and 5-7/45 pies share of the appellant in Mouza Tumhari, Tahsil Sakti, District Bilaspur, alongwith sir and khudkasht lands appurtenant thereto. The attachment was made on September 28, 1950.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (M.P. Act No. 1 of 1951) was made applicable to the area on March 31, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1951, before the sale took place, the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950  M. P. Act No. 1 of 1951  was made applicable to that area.

facts.text: Proprietary rights in the village vested in the State due to the Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of the Abolition Act the proprietary rights in the village vested in the State.

facts.text: Facts up to vesting of proprietary rights in the State are not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: Thus far there is numberdispute.

facts.text: Fields under attachment were sold on October 1, 1951 and purchased by Mohd. Hasan Khan.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1951, the fields under attachment were put to sale and were purchased by the respondent, Mohd. Hasan Khan.

facts.text: Ahmad Hafiz Khan filed application under Order 21 Rule 90 CPC objecting to the sale.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an application setting forth objections under Order 21 Rule 90 of the Code of Civil Procedure but the application was dismissed

facts.text: Sale was confirmed on February 1, 1952 after dismissal of objections.

anchor.surface_text: and the sale was companyfirmed on February 1, 1952.

facts.text: Additional District Judge, Bilaspur set aside the sale on May 1, 1952 and restored possession to Ahmad Hafiz Khan.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor appealed against the order dismissing the application and on May 1, 1952, the Additional District judge, Bilaspur, set-aside the sale, and possession of the property was restored to the appellant.

facts.text: High Court of auction purchaser reversed the order of Additional District Judge and put auction purchaser in possession on April 16, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal by the auction purchaser the order of the Additional District judge was reversed and the auction purchaser was put in possession of the property on April 16, 1955.

facts.text: Civil Judge dismissed appellant's further objection.

anchor.surface_text: The objection of the appellant was dismissed by the Civil judge

facts.text: Appeals to District Judge and High Court failed; High Court judgment dated December 24, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: and his successive appeals to the District judge and the High Court also failed. The judgment of the High Court passed on December 24, 1959,

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave: Civil Appeal No. 293 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 293 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 24, 1959

facts.text: High Court appeal was Misc. Second Appeal No. 3 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 24, 1959 of the Madhhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Second Appeal No. 3 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellant contends that cultivating rights in sir lands could not be sold in execution due to s.43 of Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant is that the cultivating rights in the sir lands companyld number be the subject matter of sale in execution of the decree in view of s. 43 of the Abolition Act.

facts.text: High Court did not accept appellant's contention.

anchor.surface_text: This argument was number accepted by the High Court

facts.text: Supreme Court sustains appellant's contention and holds sale without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The sale was, therefore, without jurisdiction, and thus illegal. ... In our opinion the companytention must be sustained.

facts.text: Attachment was before Abolition Act came into force, sale after.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the attachment was before, and the sale after the date when the Abolition Act came into force in this area.

facts.text: No mortgage or charge on cultivating rights in sir lands.

anchor.surface_text: There was numbermortgage of or charge on the cultivating rights in Sir. The decree holder Mohd. Yusaf had only a money decree

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal and sets aside sale in respect of sir lands.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the sale in respect of the sir lands appurtenant to the original proprietary share.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 4, 1963 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 4. The judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-

facts.text: Auction purchaser Mohd. Hasan Khan applied for mesne profits under s.144 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appellant and the auction purchaser applied to the executing companyrt. ... the auction purchaser asked for mesne profits under s. 144 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

and the present appeal is filed against that judgment with the special leave of this Court.
under Order 21 Rule 90 of the Code of Civil Procedure but the application was dismissed
the auction purchaser asked for mesne profits under s. 144 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Under the Central Provinces Tenancy Act, 1920, a proprietor losing his right to occupy sir land, as a proprietor became, from the date of such loss of right an occupancy tenant of sir lands. This was provided by s. 49 of the Act which, in so far as relevant to the present purpose, read as follows - 49,  1  A proprietor, who temporarily or permanently loses, whether under a decree or

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 43 MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Land held as sir-land not liable to attachment/sale for pre-vesting debts except secured by mortgage/charge on cultivating right

anchor.surface_text: Section 43 of the Abolition Act provides as follows Any land which immediately before the date of vesting, was held in absolute occupancy or occupancy right or recorded as Sir-land, shall not be liable to attachment or sale in execution of a decree or order for the recovery of any debt incurred before the date of vesting except where such debt was validly secured by mortgage of or a charge on the absolute occupancy or occupancy land or the cultivating right in the sir-land.

concepts.interpretation: Attachment does not create charge; applies to money decrees pre-vesting; sale after vesting invalid

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: l companytinue to retain the possession of his home-farm land. Home-farm is defined by s. 2  g   i  as land recorded as sir and khudkasht in the name

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 43 MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act 1951

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the words of s. 43 are quite clear and the cultivating rights in the sir and khudkash land which became under the Act the home-farm of the proprietor are protected against sale except where those cultivating rights were the subject of a mortgage or a charge created by the proprietor.

concepts.interpretation: Words clear; protects cultivating rights unless mortgaged/charged

issues.text: Whether the cultivating rights in the sir lands could be the subject matter of sale in execution of the decree in view of s. 43 of the Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: the cultivating rights in the sir lands could not be the subject matter of sale in execution of the decree in view of s. 43 of the Abolition Act.

issues.text: Whether a pre-vesting attachment creates a mortgage or charge on the cultivating rights in sir land so as to permit sale under the exception in s. 43 of the Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: There was no mortgage of or charge on the cultivating rights in Sir. The decree holder Mohd. Yusaf had only a money decree and the attachment cannot be said to have created a charge on the attached property so as to make it a secured debt within the latter part of s. 43.

issues.text: Whether pre-vesting attachment of proprietary share continues post-vesting as attachment on home-farm permitting its sale

anchor.surface_text: where it was held that after the Abolition Act an attachment of the proprietary share in the village including the Sir and khudkasht lands appurtenant thereto made before the Abolition Act got transferred to the home-farm after the appointed date. It is argued that if the attachment could subsist on the home-farm then the home-farm could also be sold.

arguments.claim: The cultivating rights in the sir lands could not be the subject matter of sale in execution of the decree in view of s. 43 of the Abolition Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Precedent did not consider s.43; attachment subsists but sale barred by s.43 unless mortgage/charge; s.43 words clear

arguments.claim: Pre-Abolition attachment does not create a mortgage or charge on cultivating rights in sir lands to qualify under exception in s.43

anchor.surface_text: There was no mortgage of or charge on the cultivating rights in Sir. The decree holder Mohd. Yusaf had only a money decree and the attachment cannot be said to have created a charge on the attached property so as to make it a secured debt within the latter part of s. 43.

arguments.claim: Words of s.43 clearly protect cultivating rights in sir/khudkasht/home-farm against sale except where subject of mortgage or charge

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the words of s. 43 are quite clear and the cultivating rights in the sir and khudkash land which became under the Act the home-farm of the proprietor are protected against sale except where those cultivating rights were the subject of a mortgage or a charge created by the proprietor.

arguments.claim: Govind Prasad precedent distinguished as it did not consider s.43 and only addressed attachment subsistence, not sale

anchor.surface_text: In the ruling the question whether a sale of the cultivating rights in the home-farm could take place after the Abolition Act came into force was not considered at all. There the attachment had been effected before the Abolition Act came into force and it was held that the attachment must continue on the home farm.

arguments.claim: Under prior Central Provinces Tenancy Act s.49, loss of proprietary right in sir land made proprietor occupancy tenant except if sold under decree directing sale of cultivating right

anchor.surface_text: Under the Central Provinces Tenancy Act, 1920, a proprietor losing his right to occupy sir land, as a proprietor became, from the date of such loss of right an occupancy tenant of sir lands. This was provided by s. 49 of the Act which, in so far as relevant to the present purpose, read as follows -

arguments.qualifiers: almost the same effect except new right created
arguments.court_reasoning: Used to explain continuity and protection of cultivating rights post-Abolition Act

holdings.text: The cultivating rights in the sir lands could not be the subject matter of sale in execution of the decree in view of s. 43 of the Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the contention must be sustained. Under the Central Provinces Tenancy Act, 1920, a proprietor losing his right to occupy sir land, as a proprietor became, from the date of such loss of right an occupancy tenant of sir lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.43 bars attachment or sale of sir lands for pre-vesting debts unless secured by mortgage or charge on cultivating rights; applies directly to facts where attachment preceded but sale followed vesting

holdings.text: Attachment in execution of money decree does not create a charge or mortgage on cultivating rights so as to qualify as secured debt under exception in s.43

anchor.surface_text: There was no mortgage of or charge on the cultivating rights in Sir. The decree holder Mohd. Yusaf had only a money decree and the attachment cannot be said to have created a charge on the attached property so as to make it a secured debt within the latter part of s. 43.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Money decree unsecured; attachment alone insufficient to create mortgage or charge required by s.43 exception

holdings.text: Pre-vesting attachment of proprietary share subsists post-vesting on home-farm but sale of home-farm barred by s.43 unless cultivating rights mortgaged or charged

anchor.surface_text: In the ruling the question whether a sale of the cultivating rights in the home-farm could take place after the Abolition Act came into force was not considered at all. There the attachment had been effected before the Abolition Act came into force and it was held that the attachment must continue on the home farm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Govind Prasad precedent distinguished as it addressed only attachment continuance, not sale; s.43 separately bars sale irrespective of attachment subsistence

holdings.text: Words of s.43 clearly protect cultivating rights in sir and khudkasht land (home-farm) against sale for pre-vesting debts except where subject to mortgage or charge created by proprietor

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the words of s. 43 are quite clear and the cultivating rights in the sir and khudkash land which became under the Act the home-farm of the proprietor are protected against sale except where those cultivating rights were the subject of a mortgage or a charge created by the proprietor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.43 mandates protection absent specific security on cultivating rights

holdings.text: Sale of sir lands in execution post-vesting was without jurisdiction and illegal

anchor.surface_text: The sale was, therefore, without jurisdiction, and thus illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No mortgage/charge; contravention of s.43 bars jurisdiction for sale

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; sale set aside in respect of sir lands appurtenant to original proprietary share

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the sale in respect of the sir lands appurtenant to the original proprietary share.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale violated s.43; remedy by setting aside sale of protected sir lands
